TopicTitle: A Kerbal's Guide to our solar system

Articles.Content:
I have found some historical records about Juturn!

Juturn gained its Gas Planet status when the super advanced mining organization, Pollux Industries, discovered that Juturn, then a Terrestrial planet, was entirely composed of the rare mineral, Unobtainium. Pollux Industries thus began to mine on the planet\'s surface. After a mere 3 months, Juturn had reduced in size to half the original, and a thick layer of pollutant smog had gathered within the atmosphere, due to the exhaust from the Pollux mining machines. After another 2 months, Pollux Industries reach Juturn\'s Handwavium core, and carted it back to Kerbin. The smogs covering Juturn, now kilometers thick and impossible to see through, compressed, and formed a much smaller planet, classed 'Gaseous' some time later. While this new planet was less than half the size of the original planet, it became the Juturn we know today.
Juturn?
Actually, we already agreed on Juturn.
Inquiring minds want to know: What is the Mun\'s surface gravity? What shall be it\'s diameter? This is critical information for mission planning purposes!
Go see the thread 'That\'s not kerbal'. You sound as if you need to learn the Kerbal way...
Is it not more Kerbal to know such ephemera ... and disregard it?
Touche...

Well, me and Harv worked out the size of the sun and kerbin\'s semimajor axis. The sun is 0.01x the mass of earth\'s sun, with a radius of 200,000 km

Kerbin orbits at a distance of 5 million km away, with an orbital period of roughly one month.

The Mun orbits kerbin over a period of 48 hours, at a distance of 13,000 km.

We have new data from Harv:

Mass: 1.756567e+28

Radius: 6.54e+07m

Gravity at surface: 27.94G

Distance from Kerbin: 13,559,014,750m

See also this thread
That\'s the current distance of the placeholder point light sun. That says nothing about what the final sun will be like.
Heh those numbers have nothing to do with the pretend lightpoint thats there now, they\'re intended physical characteristics of a future sun at that location.
Wow. Hope this is in the game!

Wow. Hope this is in the game!

in version 1.00 onwards I guess

That way when the Kerbals crash and have ouchies, they just have to step outside for antiseptic.

Actually, as a halogen an iodine atmosphere would probably be ridiculously reactive -- both on its own and as hydrogen iodide, which is highly acidic. Anyone wonder what the Kerbal skeletal system looks like?

Kerbals don\'t have ouchies. It\'s either life or death.

Really glad to see that you didn\'t just bang a \'K\' in front of everytihng.

Putting a \'K\' in front of everything is definately not the way to go about naming things.

Never leave home without it, otherwise you might get lost.

Also this

'it\'s' and 'its' are not interchangeable.

I\'ll now go and kick a puppy. No worries, it had it coming. Like anyone who confuses 'it\'s' and 'its'.

It\'s a simple mistake. I\'ll just airbrush out the apostrophes.

Or you could just shut up and ignore it and comment on the actual content.

It\'s a simple mistake. I\'ll just airbrush out the apostrophes.

Or you could just shut up and ignore it and comment on the actual content.

It\'s called 'editing'.

It\'s called 'editing'.

Diz iz tah interwabs, I do not require proper grammar.
Lol. I will still keep 'Murs' in a soft spot in my heart. Other than that, it\'s a great picture!

This concept is set to receive an overhaul, compliant with FY2012.

Included will be:

Celestia model of Kerbol system

New planetary arrangement based on community suggestions

Today\'s progress:
Fire Star seems to have an elliptical orbit?
A bit, yes, which suggests it\'s a relatively recent capture from somewhere in the outer system.

We totally need a planet shaped in the form of a donut.

Edit; ...that\'s inhabited by dinosaurs and trees.

We totally need a planet shaped in the form of a donut.

Edit; ...that\'s inhabited by dinosaurs and trees.

or a Ringworld?

or a Ringworld?

Nonono, an actual donut shaped planet, with dinosaurs on it.
